{| class="toccolours" style="float: right; clear: right; margin: 0 0 1em 1em; width: 26em;" |- ! colspan="2" style="text-align: center; background-color: #B0C4DE;" | O'RourkeâMcFadden Trophy |- | colspan="2" style="text-align: center" |    |- ! style="background: #E0E7EF;" colspan="2" | History |- | '''First Meeting''' || Clemson, 6-3 (1940) |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Last Meeting''' || Clemson, 36-14 (2011) |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Next Meeting''' || TBA |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Number of Meetings''' || 21 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''All-Time Series''' || Clemson, 10-9-2 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Largest victory''' || Tied; Clemson, 34-12 (1958); Clemson, 36-14 (2011) |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Current Streak''' || Clemson, 1 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Longest Clem Win Streak''' || 3 (1950â1952) |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Longest BC Win Streak''' || 4 (1983â2007) |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Trophy:''' || O'RourkeâMcFadden Trophy (2008âPresent) |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Trophy Series:''' || Clemson, 3-1 |} '''The O'RourkeâMcFadden Trophy''' was created in 2008 by the Boston College Gridiron Club in order to honor the tradition at [[Clemson University|Clemson]] and [[Boston College]] to honor the legacy of [[Charlie O'Rourke]] and [[Banks McFadden]], who played during the leather helmet era. The club plans to make this an annual presentation. ==Trophy history== The Boston College Gridiron Club initiated the trophy to honor the relationship between Clemson and Boston College that goes back almost 70 years. The trophy was started to recognize the efforts of Tiger fans welcoming Boston College into the ACC. The trophy features two [[leather helmet]] replicas of those used by Charlie OâRourke of Boston College and Banks McFadden of Clemson, when they competed against each other in the 1940 Cotton Bowl Classic in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]]. In addition to the trophy presentation, the Boston College Gridiron Club presents a replica leather helmet to the [[MVP]] of the winning school. The helmet will reflect the colors of the winning team. {| class="wikitable" !Year !Winner !Score !MVP !Position |- |2008 |[[2008 Clemson Tigers football team|Clemson]] |27-21 |[[C. J. Spiller]] |[[Running back|RB]] |- |2009 |[[2009 Clemson Tigers football team|Clemson]] |25-7 |Richard Jackson |[[Place kicker|PK]] |- |2010 |[[2010 Boston College Eagles football team|Boston College]] |16-10 |[[Montel Harris]] |[[Running back|RB]] |- |2011 |[[2011 Clemson Tigers football team|Clemson]] |36-14 |Chandler Catanzaro |[[Place kicker|PK]] |} ===Namesakes=== '''Charlie OâRourke''' led Boston College from the quarterback position to a 26-3-2 record in his three years as the quarterback of the Eagles between 1938-40. One of those three losses was to McFadden and Clemson in the 1940 Cotton Bowl Classic. O'Rourke later went on to play quarterback and defensive back for the [[Chicago Bears]], [[Los Angeles Dons]], and [[Baltimore Colts (1947â50)|Baltimore Colts]]. After two years as an [[NFL]] coach, he coached at [[University of Massachusetts|Massachusetts]] from 1952-59. He later served as commissioner of the [[Pop Warner Little Scholars|Pop Warner League]], a national organization of junior football teams. OâRourke had his jersey retired at Boston College and was inducted into the [[College Football Hall of Fame]] in 1972. '''Banks McFadden''' led the Tigers to a 9-1 record in 1939 as the starting quarterback. He was an All-American in football and basketball at Clemson. The 1939 football team finished 12th in the final AP poll, Clemsonâs first top 20 season on record, and the win over Boston College in the Cotton Bowl Classic was Clemsonâs first bowl appearance. In the spring of 1939 he led Clemson to the [[Southern Conference]] Basketball championship. McFadden was Clemsonâs first inductee into the College Football Hall of Fame in 1959. McFadden was the #4 overall pick of the [[1940 NFL Draft]] by the [[Brooklyn Dodgers (NFL)|Brooklyn Dodgers]]. After one year in the NFL and a stint in the [[United States Army Air Corps|Army Air Corps]] during [[World War II]], he returned to Clemson and held coaching positions in football, basketball and track. McFadden became the first coach in college basketball history to improve his conference wins in five consecutive seasons. ==Series History== Clemson first met Boston College on the football field in the 1940 [[Cotton Bowl Classic]], a 6-3 Tiger victory and the first ever bowl game for the Tigers. Over the next forty-three years, the teams met a total of thirteen times with Clemson winning six of eleven meetings. In 2005, Boston College joined the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] and was placed in the Atlantic Division. Since then, the divisional match-up has been played on an annual basis with Boston College leading the series 4-3. As of 2011, Clemson leads the all-time series at 10-9-2. ===Game results=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%" !Date !Winner !Score !Location !Attendance !Series |-style="background-color:#FF6300; color:#330066" |January 1, 1940||Clemson||
